children.subject:
This would be something to ask the 5th Year MS advisors, but I think the general answer would be no, i.e. you would have just been expected to take any necessary undergrad courses as an undergrad. However, stranger petitions have been granted in the past. 

That being said, upper-division classes do count for the breadth requirement for sure.

history.content: You could take an upper division course as long as you meet the minimum requirements for the M.S.: at least 10 units of graduate-level EECS courses, at least 8 units of breadth courses outside EECS, and a certain number of 299 units, depending on your MS plan. Plus a total of at least 24 units.

For the 5th year MS, if there is an upper division course that is relevant to my research area, can I take it and use it to satisfy the EECS coursework requirement? For instance, I might want to learn about compilers, but the graduate classes in compilers (CS 263 and 264) have CS 164 as a prerequisite, so it would be better to take CS 164.
history.subject: Using Upper Division Courses for 5th year MS
